data.title: Harry Shearer: a career timeline
data.meta_description: The life and work of Harry Shearer, star of The Simpsons and Spinal Tap.
data.text:
Harry Shearer

1943 Born in Los Angeles, California, Shearer became an actor at the age of seven.

1953 Made his film debut in Abbott and Costello Go to Mars. A larger part came later that year in The Robe.

1960s Shearer attended UCLA as a political science major.

1967 Became a high school teacher, teaching English and social studies.

1969 Was a member of a radio comedy group, also performing in comedy clubs and concert venues.

1979 Shearer was hired as a writer and cast member on Saturday Night Live.

1983 Began as host of the comedy and music radio programme Le Show.

1984 Co-created, co-wrote and co-starred in Rob Reiner’s film This Is Spinal Tap, satirizing the wild behaviour and musical pretensions of hard rock and heavy metal bands.

1988-98 Made film appearances in The Fisher King, A League of Their Own, The Truman Show, My Best Friend’s Wedding and Small Soilders.

1988-2001 Made TV appearances in Miami Vice, The Golden Girls, Ellen, Friends, Chicago Hope, ER, Dawson’s Creek, and That’s Life.

1989-present Shearer’s most prolific work has been as a voice actor on The Simpsons. He provides voices for 21 of the characters – among them are: Mr Burns, Waylon Smithers, Ned Flanders, Reverend Timothy Lovejoy, Kent Brockman, Dr Julius Hibbert, Lenny Leonard, Principal Skinner, Otto Man, Rainer Wolfcastle, and Dr Marvin Monroe.

2002 Directed his first film, Teddy Bear’s Picnic.

2003 Shearer starred with Spinal Tap collaborators Christopher Guest and Michael McKean in the folk music mockumentary A Mighty Wind.

2006 Starred in Christopher Guest's comedy film For Your Consideration about film awards.

2010 Won a Grammy Award for the Best Comedy-Album with Back from the Dead, which features re-recorded versions of songs from This Is Spinal Tap.
